title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key outcomes of protest, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to the formation of new governments.

options.label: B
options.text: It can force out tyrants and activate people who have long been on the sidelines of civic life.

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to the establishment of new economic systems.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to the abolition of social media.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first strategy for turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power?

options.label: A
options.text: Choose a defining fight.

options.label: B
options.text: Find an early win.

options.label: C
options.text: Expand the frame of the possible.

options.label: D
options.text: Mobilize voters.

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to "expand the frame of the possible"?

options.label: A
options.text: It means to define the boundaries of civic imagination and what is achievable.

options.label: B
options.text: It means pushing those boundaries outward to ask what if.

options.label: C
options.text: It means asking questions that challenge conventional politics.

options.label: D
options.text: It means defining the terms of a debate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second strategy for turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power?

options.label: A
options.text: Expand the frame of the possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Choose a defining fight.

options.label: C
options.text: Find an early win.

options.label: D
options.text: Mobilize voters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of choosing a defining fight?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a sharp contrast between different ideas or policies.

options.label: B
options.text: To define the boundaries of civic imagination.

options.label: C
options.text: To expand the frame of the possible.

options.label: D
options.text: To mobilize voters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third strategy for turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power?

options.label: A
options.text: Expand the frame of the possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Choose a defining fight.

options.label: C
options.text: Find an early win.

options.label: D
options.text: Mobilize voters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of finding an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: To create momentum and change what people think is possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To define the terms of a debate.

options.label: C
options.text: To expand the frame of the possible.

options.label: D
options.text: To mobilize voters.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how finding an early win can lead to lasting change?

options.label: A
options.text: The Arab Spring.

options.label: B
options.text: The Indian Independence movement.

options.label: C
options.text: The Czech self-determination movement.

options.label: D
options.text: The U.S. Civil Rights Movement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the spirit of protest, and what is the speaker's message?

options.label: A
options.text: The spirit of protest is powerful, but showing up after the protest is what matters.

options.label: B
options.text: The spirit of protest is weak, and people should not bother showing up.

options.label: C
options.text: The spirit of protest is not important, and people should focus on other issues.

options.label: D
options.text: The spirit of protest is not relevant, and people should not care.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: You don't have to be anyone special to be part of this grind and make a difference.

options.label: B
options.text: You have to be someone special to make a difference.

options.label: C
options.text: You can't make a difference on your own.

options.label: D
options.text: You have to be part of a group to make a difference.

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self assembly?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where unordered parts come together in an organized structure completely on their own.

options.label: B
options.text: A process where parts are assembled by humans.

options.label: C
options.text: A process where objects are broken down into smaller parts.

options.label: D
options.text: A process where objects are combined with other materials.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between our bodies and man-made objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Our bodies are made of living cells, while man-made objects are made of non-living materials.

options.label: B
options.text: Our bodies can regrow and repair themselves, while man-made objects cannot.

options.label: C
options.text: Our bodies are made of metal, while man-made objects are made of plastic.

options.label: D
options.text: Our bodies are made of wood, while man-made objects are made of metal.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly in biology?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of a snowflake.

options.label: B
options.text: The folding of a protein into a 3-D structure.

options.label: C
options.text: The replication of DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly in chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of a crystal.

options.label: B
options.text: The reaction between two chemicals.

options.label: C
options.text: The folding of a protein into a 3-D structure.

options.label: D
options.text: The replication of DNA.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly in technology?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of a snowflake.

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of a molecular microchip.

options.label: C
options.text: The replication of DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: The folding of a protein into a 3-D structure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of using self assembly in technology?

options.label: A
options.text: It can make objects more durable.

options.label: B
options.text: It can make objects more adaptive.

options.label: C
options.text: It can make objects more reliant on fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: It can make objects more expensive.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of a snowflake.

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of a city.

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of a galaxy.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of using self assembly in construction?

options.label: A
options.text: It can make buildings more durable.

options.label: B
options.text: It can make buildings more adaptive.

options.label: C
options.text: It can make buildings more reliant on fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: It can make buildings more expensive.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self assembly in a biological system?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of a virus.

options.label: B
options.text: The folding of a protein into a 3-D structure.

options.label: C
options.text: The replication of DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of using self assembly in medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: It can make medical devices more durable.

options.label: B
options.text: It can make medical devices more adaptive.

options.label: C
options.text: It can make medical devices more reliant on fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: It can make medical devices more expensive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term "cognitive diversity" referring to?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to think and solve problems in a similar way to others.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to think and solve problems in a unique and different way.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to communicate and collaborate with others.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to work independently and make decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a group of people with similar perspectives work together on a complex problem?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their solution and have a higher chance of success.

options.label: B
options.text: They become less confident in their solution and have a lower chance of success.

options.label: C
options.text: They are able to deliver the solution more efficiently.

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to think and solve problems in a unique and different way.

multiple-choice.question: Why are people attracted to others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they want to learn from them and improve their skills.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it makes them feel smarter and validates their worldview.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they want to work independently and make decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they want to communicate and collaborate with others.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with surrounding oneself with like-minded others when working on complex problems?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no problem, it is beneficial to work with people who think like you.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to a lack of cognitive diversity and a decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to a lack of creativity and innovation.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to a lack of confidence in one's solution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive diversity is not important and will not be a key feature of competitive advantage.

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive diversity is important and will be a key feature of competitive advantage.

options.label: C
options.text: Innovation and creativity are the key features of competitive advantage.

options.label: D
options.text: Communication and collaboration are the key features of competitive advantage.

multiple-choice.question: What did the economist say about working with people who think like him?

options.label: A
options.text: He said it was a bad idea and that he should work with people who think differently.

options.label: B
options.text: He said it was a good idea and that he should work with people who think like him.

options.label: C
options.text: He said it was a neutral idea and that it didn't matter who he worked with.

options.label: D
options.text: He said it was a bad idea and that he should work with people who think differently.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with mirroring each other's perspectives when working on complex problems?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to a lack of cognitive diversity and a decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to a lack of creativity and innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to a lack of confidence in one's solution.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to a lack of communication and collaboration.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that the speaker is trying to make a point about?

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of cognitive diversity and its importance.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of innovation and creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of communication and collaboration.

options.label: D
options.text: The concept of competitive advantage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea that the speaker is trying to convey about working in teams?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is beneficial to work with people who think like you.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is beneficial to work with people who think differently.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is neutral whether you work with people who think like you or differently.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is not beneficial to work in teams.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key takeaway from the speaker's argument about cognitive diversity?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is not important and will not be a key feature of competitive advantage.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is important and will be a key feature of competitive advantage.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is neutral and does not matter whether you work with people who think like you or differently.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is not beneficial to work in teams.
